facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 324 and 325 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 10, 1953, of the former Hyderabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 10, 1953, of the former Hyderabad High Court in E.P.T. References Nos. 45215 and 453/5 of 1358 F. V. Viswanatha Sastri, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the appellant.

facts.text: High Court cases in E.P.T. References Nos. 45215 and 453/5 of 1358 F.

anchor.surface_text: dated April 10, 1953, of the former Hyderabad High Court in E.P.T. References Nos. 45215 and 453/5 of 1358 F. V. Viswanatha Sastri, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the appellant. N. Rajagopal Sastri and D. Gupta, for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 18, 1960 by K. DAS, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. April 18. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-These are two appeals with special leave from the Judgment and Order of the High Court of Hyderabad dated April 10, 1953, in two references under s. 48 3  of the Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Act.

facts.text: Two appeals with special leave from Judgment and Order of High Court of Hyderabad dated April 10, 1953, in two references under s. 48(3) of Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: These are two appeals with special leave from the Judgment and Order of the High Court of Hyderabad dated April 10, 1953, in two references under s. 48 3  of the Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Act. The question which the High Court answered against the assesses in the said references was- Whether in the circumstances of the case, the officers of the Excess-Profits Tax Department were right in treating the income of the assessee or the Industrial Trust Fund as income from business.

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the affirmative against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the affirmative. The point for decision before us is if the High Court companyrectly answered the question. The relevant facts which led to the question and answer are these.

facts.text: Two cotton mills called Azamjahi mills and Osmanshahi mills in the State of Hyderabad, public joint stock companies.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts which led to the question and answer are these. There were two cotton mills in the State of Hyderabad  as it was then known  called Azamjahi mills and Osmanshahi mills. They were public joint stock companies.

facts.text: Firman-e-Mubarak of 1929 issued by Ruler of Hyderabad State formed Industrial Trust Fund to help large and small industries.

anchor.surface_text: By a Firman-e-Mubarak of 1929 issued by the then Ruler of the State was formed an institution called the Industrial Trust Fund, the purpose of which was to help large and small industries on behalf of the Government of the State.

facts.text: Management of Industrial Trust Fund entrusted to Committee of three members of Government called Trustees.

anchor.surface_text: The management of the Trust was entrusted to a Committee which companysisted of three members of the Government, who were called Trustees.

facts.text: By agreements dated April 12, 1934 and July 27, 1934, Trustees appointed secretaries, treasurers and agents of Azamjahi and Osmanshahi mills.

anchor.surface_text: By two agreements dated April 12, 1934, and July 27, 1934, made between the Trustees of the one part and the two mills of the other, the Trustees were appointed secretaries, treasurers and agents of the said mills.

facts.text: Under 1934 agreements, Trustees given general conduct and management of business of mills, entitled to appoint employees and delegate powers subject to Board of Directors approval.

anchor.surface_text: Under these agreements the Trustees were given the general companyduct and management of the business and affairs of the mills and they were entitled to appoint employees and were also entitled to delegate to other persons all or any of the powers, authorities, discretions, etc., under the agreements subject to the approval of the Board of Directors of the respective mills.

facts.text: By two other agreements dated April 12, 1934 and July 27, 1934, Trustees appointed selling agents of the mills.

anchor.surface_text: By two other agreements also dated April 12, 1934, and July 27, 1934, the Trustees were appointed selling agents of the mills.

facts.text: By two agreements dated October 16, 1938 supplemental to selling agency agreements, Trustees given power to delegate powers subject to Board approval.

anchor.surface_text: By two agreements both dated October 16, 1938, which were supplemental to the selling agency agreements mentioned above, the Trustees were given power to delegate all or any of their powers, authorities, etc., to other persons subject to the approval of the Board of Directors of the respective mills.

facts.text: Till October 1938, Trustees exercised powers through Advisory Board; Quamar Shaffi Tyabji appointed chairman on Rs. 1,500 per month plus commission.

anchor.surface_text: Till October, 1938, the Trustees exercised their powers and performed their functions under the agreements aforesaid through an Advisory Board, and Quamar Shaffi Tyabji, appellant before us, was appointed chairman of the Advisory Board on a remuneration of Rs. 1,500 per month plus a certain companymission.

facts.text: Sometime in 1938 Advisory Board dissolved.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in 1938 the Advisory Board was dissolved, and on December 6, 1938, an agreement was entered into between the Trustees and the appellant.

facts.text: Agreement dated December 6, 1938 between Trustees and appellant Quamar Shaffi Tyabji appointing him managing agent.

anchor.surface_text: and on December 6, 1938, an agreement was entered into between the Trustees and the appellant. Clause 11 of the preamble of this agreement recited The said Trustees are desirous of delegating such of the powers, authorities and discretions as such secretaries, treasurers and agents as also as such selling agents of the said two mills as aforesaid as are hereinafter mentioned to and appointing the said Quamar Shaffi Tyabjee as the managing agent of the business of the said trustees as such secretaries and treasurers and agents as also as such selling agents of the said two mills as aforesaid in and for the matters and purposes hereinafter mentioned.

facts.text: Under December 6, 1938 agreement, full powers of management and selling agency delegated to appellant subject to general control of Trustees.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the full powers of management and of the selling agency in relation to both the mills were delegated to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant assessed to excess profits tax for chargeable accounting period 1351F corresponding to October 1, 1941 to September 30, 1942; total income Rs. 2,37,451 including Rs. 2,11,230 managing agency allowance and commission.

anchor.surface_text: He was assessed to excess profits tax for the two chargeable accounting periods 1351F and 1352F, companyresponding to October 1, 1941, to September 30, 1942, and October 1, 1942, to September 30, 1943, respectively. The total income assessed for 1351F was Rs. 2,37,451, which included a sum of Rs. 2,11,230 representing the appellants managing agency allowance and companymission.

facts.text: Appellant assessed to excess profits tax for chargeable accounting period 1352F corresponding to October 1, 1942 to September 30, 1943; total income Rs. 4,90,027 including Rs. 4,45,775 managing agency commission and allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The total income for 1352F was Rs. 4,90,027 which included Rs. 4,45,775 being the managing agency companymission and allowance of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant contended before Excess Profits Tax authorities that he was employee of Industrial Trust Fund, remuneration was salary not income from business, not liable to excess profits tax.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Excess Profits Tax authorities the appellant companytended that he was only an employee of the Industrial Trust Fund and his remuneration under the agreement dated December 6, 1938, was merely salary and number income derived from business and therefore number liable to excess profits tax.

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax authorities negatived appellant's contention.

anchor.surface_text: The Excess Profits Tax authorities negatived this companytention, and as required by the High Court the Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad, referred the question of law which we have set out at the beginning of this judg- ment to the High Court for decision.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad referred question of law to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and as required by the High Court the Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad, referred the question of law which we have set out at the beginning of this judg- ment to the High Court for decision.

facts.text: Appellant conducted business of the mills both as management and selling under 1938 agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of the agreement dated December 6, 1938, the appellant companyducted the business of the mills, both as to management and selling.

facts.text: Quamar Shaffi Tyabji is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: and Quamar Shaffi Tyabji, appellant before us, was appointed chairman of the Advisory Board on a remuneration of Rs. 1,500 per month plus a certain companymission.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that appellant was carrying on business of managing agency.

anchor.surface_text: We have numberdoubt in our minds that what clearly emerges from the terms of the agreement of December 6, 1938, is a business of managing agency accepted and undertaken by the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant had previous business experience and held agency of Eastern Federal Union Insurance Co. bringing substantial income.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a man with previous business experience and held an agency of the Eastern Federal Union Insurance Co., which brought him a substantial income.

Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 10, 1953, of the former Hyderabad High Court in E.P.T. References Nos. 45215 and 453/5 of 1358 F. V. Viswanatha Sastri, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the appellant.

1960. April 18. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-These are two appeals with special leave from the Judgment and Order of the High Court of Hyderabad dated April 10, 1953, in two references under s. 48 3  of the Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Act.

These are two appeals with special leave from the Judgment and Order of the High Court of Hyderabad dated April 10, 1953, in two references under s. 48 3  of the Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Act. The question which the High Court answered against the assesses in the said references was- Whether in the circumstances of the case, the officers of the Excess-Profits Tax Department were right in treating the income of the assessee or the Industrial Trust Fund as income from business.

anchor.surface_text: under s. 48 3  of the Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Act. The question which the High Court answered against the assesses in the said references was- Whether in the circumstances of the case, the officers of the Excess-Profits Tax Department were right in treating the income of the assessee or the Industrial Trust Fund as income from business. , The High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

concepts.interpretation: Managing agency remuneration and commission constitutes income derived from business, liable to excess profits tax.

anchor.surface_text: The position in law was as laid down in s. 194 of the Indian Contract Act. In similar circumstances this Court has held that managing agency is business  see Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal and Son Ltd. v. The Government of Hyderabad  1  and J. K. Trust, Bombay v. The Commissioner of Income-tax Excess Profits Tax, Bombay  2  .

anchor.surface_text: In Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal and Son Ltd. V. The Government of Hyderabad  1  this Court had occasion to explain the position of an agent, a servant and an independent contractor. It was there pointed out that the difference between the relations of master and servant and of principal and agent lay in this a principal has the right to direct what work the agent has to do but a master has the further right to direct how the work is to be done.

concepts.interpretation: Appellant distinguished from servant (no direct control on how work done) and held to be agent of mills via sub-delegation by trustees.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: opal and Son Ltd. V. The Government of Hyderabad  1  this Court had occasion to explain the position of an agent, a servant and an independent company

Trust, Bombay v. The Commissioner of Income-tax Excess Profits Tax, Bombay  2  . A consideration of the terms of the agreement of December 6, 1938, also leaves no manner of doubt, in the matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of binding Supreme Court precedents to identical managing agency by Trustees of Hyderabad mills.

holdings.text: The managing agency agreement must be read as a whole, and so read the conclusion which clearly emerges is that the appellant was undertaking a business of his own in accepting the duties and responsibilities of a managing agent of the two mills under the general control of the Trustees.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.9 (non-assignment, personal) does not change relation to master-servant when read holistically with delegation, powers, remuneration clauses indicating business undertaking.

holdings.text: We do not think that that decision gives any help to the appellant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction in Companies Act definitions (managing agent vs manager) irrelevant; determinative is construction of agreements, not statutory labels.
